title: Island Whales and the Ancient Whale Theory
summary: The appearance of Island Whales in Episode 574 reinforces the theory that there was a massive whale companion to Joy Boy's crew, similar to how Laboon was a companion to the Rumbar Pirates and how Zunesha follows a similar pattern as a giant elephant.
fullText: Fans theorize that the recurring motif of Island Whales throughout One Piece is not coincidental. Just as Laboon was a companion to Brook's crew 50 years ago, and the Island Whales in Episode 574 respond to Binks' Sake, there may have been an ancient whale that accompanied Joy Boy during the Void Century. This theory is supported by the parallel between Zunesha (the giant elephant) and the possibility of a similarly massive whale. The whales' positive response to Binks' Sake suggests this song may have been known in the ancient past, potentially connecting it to Joy Boy's era. The theory proposes that destroying the Red Line (which Laboon headbutts) may be connected to reuniting separated whale pods and fulfilling ancient promises.
author: One Piece Theory Community

source.title: One Piece Theory: Bink's Sake Is the Key to the One Piece

title: Binks' Sake Contains the Key to the One Piece
summary: The fact that Island Whales universally respond to Binks' Sake suggests the song contains hidden significance. Some theorize it may contain clues to finding the One Piece or may have been the song of the original pirate crew from the Void Century.
fullText: The song Binks' Sake has appeared multiple times throughout One Piece, and its universal recognition by Island Whales (as seen in Episode 574) suggests it has deeper significance than just being a pirate drinking song. Fans theorize that the lyrics may contain encrypted information about the location of the One Piece, the true history of the Void Century, or instructions for destroying the Red Line. The theory points to how the song predates even Brook's time with the Rumbar Pirates, suggesting it could be centuries old. The whales' response to it implies an ancestral memory, possibly passed down from a time when Joy Boy's crew included a whale companion. Some theorists believe that when the Straw Hats finally reach Laugh Tale, they will discover that Binks' Sake was the song sung by the original crew who left the One Piece treasure.
author: One Piece Theorists

source.title: One Piece Theory: Bink's Sake Foreshadows the Story's End

title: Brook and Laboon's Reunion Will Trigger the Red Line's Destruction
summary: The emotional setup in Episode 574 with the Island Whales reinforces the theory that Brook's eventual reunion with Laboon will be tied to the story's climax and potentially the destruction of the Red Line.
fullText: Episode 574's touching moment with the Island Whales serves as a reminder of Brook's promise to reunite with Laboon, who has been waiting at Reverse Mountain for 50 years. Fans theorize that this reunion won't just be an emotional payoff but will be intrinsically connected to the series' endgame. The theory suggests that destroying the Red Line (which separates the seas and which Laboon continuously headbutts) will reunite separated whale pods, symbolically and literally bringing together what was divided. When the Straw Hats complete their journey around the world and return to where they started, Brook's reunion with Laboon while playing Binks' Sake will coincide with the destruction of the Red Line, creating the All Blue and uniting the world's oceans. This would make the promise between a skeleton and a whale one of the most important plot threads in the entire series.
author: One Piece Fan Community

source.title: One Piece; 3rd Theory; Brook and Laboon's reunion

title: The Red Sea Symbolism of the New World Entrance
summary: The red sea encountered in Episode 574 when entering the New World carries biblical symbolism about crossing into a promised land through trial, foreshadowing the crew's journey ahead.
fullText: When the Straw Hats emerge into the New World in Episode 574, they encounter red seas that Sanji describes as 'a sea of flames' and Zoro calls 'the entrance to hell.' This vivid imagery has sparked theories about its symbolic significance. Some fans draw parallels to the biblical parting of the Red Sea, suggesting that the Straw Hats' journey through the New World represents crossing into a promised land through trial and tribulation. The hellish appearance contrasts with Luffy's optimistic 'Perfect!' response, symbolizing how the crew transforms danger into opportunity. Others theorize that the red color foreshadows the blood that will be shed in the New World, or represents the Revolutionary Army's coming war. The 'sea of flames' description may also foreshadow encounters with fire-based powers or the revelation of ancient weapons. The fact that they enter through the aid of whales (who are associated with ancient history and Joy Boy) rather than through conventional means may signify that they are following a path meant for those destined to change the world.
author: One Piece Symbolism Analysts
